Award.AwardTitle: Comparison of Thermal and Non-Thermal Protocols for Analysis of Isoprene Secondary Organic Aerosol (SOA) Generated under Conditions of Low Nitrogen Oxides (NOx)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is focused on laboratory studies of the formation of secondary organic aerosol (SOA) in the atmosphere derived from the presence of isoprene. Isoprene is a compound produced and emitted by many species of trees and other plant materials. Experiments will be conducted in a laboratory chamber to investigate the formation of SOA and assess the possible presence of artifacts related to the use of certain experimental methods.

This study includes an in-depth, quantitative, molecular-level investigation of isoprene-SOA composition and aging. The objectives of the research are to: (1) synthesize standards to investigate artifact formation and to identify labile components degraded during conventional thermal GC-ESI/MS analysis of isoprene SOA formed under low-nitrogen oxide (NOx) conditions; (2) optimize hydrophilic interaction liquid chromatography (HILIC) protocols for separation of synthetic targets and SOA extracts; and (3) conduct an analysis of the SOA particles and identification of analytical artifacts/decomposition products by comparison of results from HILIC and GC/EI-MS protocols.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have combined synthetic chemistry with state-of-the-art analytical techniques to verify the structures and formation mechanisms of isoprene-derived components of fine particulate to settle a debate that has been ongoing since isoprene was first recognized as a source of fine particulates. We have found that the compounds arise both from particle phase reactions of a major isoprene atmospheric oxidation product but are also artifacts created by conventional analytical protocols. As a consequence, measurements of fine particulate composition are inaccurate. Data reported by the conventional derivatization of fine particulate extracts followed by gas chromatographic analysis need to be reexamined and reinterpreted. Based on smog chamber experiments, we have also demonstrated that a significant proportion of the newly characterized compounds evaporate from fine particulates into the atmosphere and therefore escape measurement, leading to inaccurate estimates of atmospheric carbon.

 

We have resolved a second debate concerning the structure of an important isoprene oxidation product by using a newly developed technology in mass spectrometry called ion mobility spectrometry, which allows mass spectrometric separation of compounds in a gas phase mixture that have identical chemical compositions but different structures. The previously accepted structure of this compound was predicted to be rapidly degraded by ambient ultraviolet radiation; however, the true structure is resistant to UV degradation and can be oxidized to low-volatility products that condense onto fine particulates. The oxidation products we have observed are a previously unrecognized source of organic particulate matter.

 

The organic portion of fine particulates contains high molecular weight, non-volatile compounds derived by coupling of reactive gas phase products of isoprene oxidation once they have been absorbed at particle surfaces. The formation reactions and the behavior of the high molecular weight particulate components during analytical procedures is currently not well understood. We have developed a synthetic route to coupling two major low molecular weight components to form a well-defined high molecular weight mixture that can be used as a proxy to study this behavior.

 

The standards synthesized for this project will have the immediate impact of improving analytical accuracy of the composition of ambient fine particulates by avoiding the use of proxies as standards to quantitate fine particulate components. Improvements in analysis can then be implemented in calibrating and assessing existing models of atmospheric processes. The insights provided into the time-dependent evolution of fine particulate composition and physicochemical properties in isoprene-rich regions will further contribute towards improving modeling efforts. Newly available synthetic standards for quantitation of precursors and products from this project will enable refinement of atmospheric transformation pathways of isoprene and the further reactions of the initially formed products. Insights gained from this information can be used in developing new models that will improve predictions of how atmospheric chemistry will be affected by changes in pollutant levels accompanying implementation of emissions regulations. Altogether, improved modeling of different aspects of atmospheric processes on both global and regional scales will advance our understanding of how pollution control and land use policies will affect climate change and will aid in developing policies which minimize effects of anthropogenic activity.

Fine particulates are known to cause oxidative stress in the respiratory system leading to adverse health outcomes. This project has identified specific components that cause oxidative stress and developed synthetic routes to synthesis of those compounds so that they are available in sufficient amounts for toxicological studies. We have provided the compounds to respiratory toxicologists studying the responses of airway cells to fine particulates. Thus, the syntheses developed during this project will be important to understanding the health effects which will in turn inform rational development of effective emissions standards for protecting the general population.

Overall, this project will advance the ability of society to formulate pollution control regulations that protect populations and minimize climate change.
